message_1: A sample of radioactive material has a half-life of 10 days. If the initial amount of the material is 100 grams, what will be the amount of material remaining after 30 days?
message_2:
To calculate the remaining amount of radioactive material after a certain number of days, we can use the formula:

Remaining amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount is 100 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 30 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Remaining amount = 100 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)
Remaining amount = 100 * (1/2)^3
Remaining amount = 100 * (1/8)
Remaining amount = 12.5 grams

So, after 30 days, there will be 12.5 grams of the radioactive material remaining.
